newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian oil price hike inevitable - securities firm.
newsitem.headline: Indian oil price hike inevitable - securities firm.

text.p: India cannot avoid raising its state-fixed petroleum product prices, securities firm SBI Capital Markets Ltd (SBICAP) said on Tuesday.
"Petroleum products price hike is inevitable to get out of the unsustainable situation caused by high oil pool account deficit," SBICAP said in a research report.
India's oil pool account reconciles the state-fixed administered pricing mechanism with free market conditions.
The oil pool account is a balancing mechanism whereby refineries are compensated for subsidised prices of several petroleum products in India.
The oil pool account deficit for 1996/97 (April-March) is estimated to be running a deficit of 155 billion rupees ($4.3 billion).
"We estimate that a 20 percent hike across the board would be necessary to wipe out the year end oil pool account deficit,"SBICAP said.
It said mounting unpaid dues to refining firms from the oil pool has led to a working capital problems.
"The oil companies are expected to resort to short-term debt funds leading to high interest expense," the report said.
It said Indian refiners are expected to achieve 35 percent to 40 percent earnings growth in 1998/99 (April-March) as new projects get commissioned.
Supply of oil shares would increase over the next three to four years as the government brings down its stake to 51 percent, SBICAP said.
SBICAP expects local supply of refined products to catch up with demand as refining capacity increases by 130 percent to reach 139 million tonnes per year by 2001/02.
"However, reliance on imports will continue as crude production is likely to stagnate," it said.
SBICAP expects India's demand for petroleum production to increase by an annual 8.3 percent over the next five years.
India's three leading refiners are Indian Oil Corp Ltd, Bharat Petroleum Corp Ltd and Hindustan Petroelum Corp Ltd -- all of them state-controlled.
